Using scholarly style and language, elaborate in detail (from the standpoint of contributions made to lexical semantics) on the following paragraph, citing examples from the particular work mentioned and provide page numbe wherever applicable: Cognitive semantics - George Lakoff (1987) and Ronald Langacker (1987)
The cognitive turn in linguistics in the 1970s and 1980s led to the development of cognitive semantics, an approach that emphasizes the role of mental representation and cognitive processes in shaping linguistic meaning. Two key figures in this movement were George Lakoff and Ronald Langacker. Lakoff's "Women, Fire, and Dangerous Things" (1987) proposed that categories in language are organized around prototypes, while Langacker's "Foundations of Cognitive Grammar" (1987) argued that meaning arises from the interaction of linguistic forms and cognitive structures.
